Award.AwardTitle: Solution-Based Fabrication of Coherent Nanocomposite Film Electrodes for Li-Ion Batteries

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research objectives of this award are (1) to develop environmentally benign strategies for the fabrication of coherent nanocomposite film electrodes consisting of pseudocrystalline transition metal oxides or transition metal phosphates uniformly coated with nano carbon, (2) to study film electrodes with electroactive materials away from thermodynamic equilibrium for much higher energy storage capacity with high power density, and (3) to achieve a better fundamental understanding of the dependence of crystallinity, nanostructures, and energy storage performance on the fabrication methods and parameters. Specific approaches include the deposition of homogeneous organic-inorganic nanocomposite films through water electrolysis induced co-precipitation or electrophoretic deposition, and the formation of coherent nanocomposite films consisting of pseudocrystalline electroactive materials uniformly coated with nano carbon through controlled pyrolysis and partial crystallization.

If successful, this research will lead to the development of large-scale fabrication methods for coherent porous nanocomposite films readily available for thin film lithium-ion battery manufacturing, and the synthesis of film electrodes with greatly enhanced energy storage density and specific power as well as cyclic stability. This research will have impacts beyond the electrical energy storage materials, as the manufacturing methods can be directly applied in the fabrication of various organic-inorganic nanocomposite or hybrid films for other applications including, but not limited to, corrosion protection or wear resistant coatings, porous films for sensors, and catalysis. This research will greatly benefit both graduate and undergraduate students through introducing and attracting them to the field of sustainable clean energy materials and novel manufacturing strategies, and through fostering a positive culture among them that accepts, respects, and tolerates differences of others.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have designed, fabricated and studied various nanostructured electrodes for lithium-ion batteries that far exceed currently achieved lithium-ion intercalation capacity and display significantly high charge and discharge capability. Various nanostructures of V2O5, LiFePO4, and Li4Ti5O12 have been synthesized by solution methods including sol-gel processing, hydrothermal growth, and electrophoretic deposition. We have intentionally controlled the crystallinity and introduced surface defects through annealing at low temperature and reactive gases. Such nanostructured V2O5, LiFePO4, and Li4Ti5O12 films and electrodes have demonstrated excellent discharge capacities, far exceeding the theoretical limits of their bulk counterparties that consist of micrometer-sized well crystallized particles. In addition to the advancement in synthesis and fundamental understanding of nanostructures and defects on the energy storage properties, this research has developed a simple solution-based process to manufacture a large quantity of desired nanostructured vanadium pentoxide with demonstrated excellent lithium-ion insertion properties. Figure 1 shows the leaf-like V2O5 nanocrystallites made by sol-gel processing followed with freeze drying. Figure 1a shows the formation of thin sheets of V2O5 measuring several tens of micrometers after annealing at 450 °C. Higher magnification SEM, Figure 1b, reveals that the sheets are 60-80 nm thick, and further reveals that the sheets are polycrystalline. The high energy (100) and (001) facets of adjacent crystallites are closely connected to reduce the total surface energy. These V2O5 sheet crystallites have demonstrated a very good lithium ion intercalation capacity, ~ 310 mAh/g, at the intercalation rate of 50 mA/g. Such processing route is anticipated to be applicable to the fabrication of other nanostructured materials for energy storage. This research has resulted in 23 journal papers published or accepted for publication and 1 international patent application.

This grant has provided partial financial support to 3 PhD students: Dr. Yanyi Liu (female, final defense on December 14, 2011), Dr. Stephanie Candelaria (Hispanic, graduated on August 22, 2013), and Mr. Evan Uchaker (Hispanic, 4th year and continuing). 3 exchange PhD students (Laifa Shen, Nan Zhou, and Ming Zhang) and 1 visiting professor’s (Yanwei Li) research was also partially supported by this grant (materials and supplies). In addition, 2 undergraduate students did their senior research projects with the graduate students.


Last Modified: 09/10/2013
Modified by: Guozhong Cao

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: We have designed, fabricated and studied various nanostructured electrodes for lithium-ion batteries that far exceed currently achieved lithium-ion intercalation capacity and display significantly high charge and discharge capability. Various nanostructures of V2O5, LiFePO4, and Li4Ti5O12 have been synthesized by solution methods including sol-gel processing, hydrothermal growth, and electrophoretic deposition. We have intentionally controlled the crystallinity and introduced surface defects through annealing at low temperature and reactive gases. Such nanostructured V2O5, LiFePO4, and Li4Ti5O12 films and electrodes have demonstrated excellent discharge capacities, far exceeding the theoretical limits of their bulk counterparties that consist of micrometer-sized well crystallized particles. In addition to the advancement in synthesis and fundamental understanding of nanostructures and defects on the energy storage properties, this research has developed a simple solution-based process to manufacture a large quantity of desired nanostructured vanadium pentoxide with demonstrated excellent lithium-ion insertion properties. Figure 1 shows the leaf-like V2O5 nanocrystallites made by sol-gel processing followed with freeze drying. Figure 1a shows the formation of thin sheets of V2O5 measuring several tens of micrometers after annealing at 450 °C. Higher magnification SEM, Figure 1b, reveals that the sheets are 60-80 nm thick, and further reveals that the sheets are polycrystalline. The high energy (100) and (001) facets of adjacent crystallites are closely connected to reduce the total surface energy. These V2O5 sheet crystallites have demonstrated a very good lithium ion intercalation capacity, ~ 310 mAh/g, at the intercalation rate of 50 mA/g. Such processing route is anticipated to be applicable to the fabrication of other nanostructured materials for energy storage. This research has resulted in 23 journal papers published or accepted for publication and 1 international patent application.
